awd_titl_txt: Conference: The Adjoint School: A Training Program for New Researchers in Applied Category Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports US-based participants in the Adjoint School Research Week, held at the University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, UK over July 11–15, 2022. The Adjoint School 2022 provides mentorship and community for early-career researchers in applied category theory, bringing them together for fortnightly virtual collaboration from February to June, and then in person for the Adjoint School Research Week, followed by the International Conference on Applied Category Theory. Held annually, the Adjoint School is a student-led, international, hands-on research training program serving 16-20 new students each year, with previous participants returning as teaching assistants and organizers. Adjoint School projects center on using techniques in category theory -- a mathematical language of systems and relationships -- to solve practical problems in science and engineering, relevant to both academic and industry needs. At core, the school is designed around community-building, reflecting the strongly social nature of mathematics research. As part of this, the school is especially committed to advancing inclusivity, access, and diversity in the applied category theory research community, and in the mathematics community more broadly.
 
In 2022, the Adjoint School comprises the following projects and mentors: Compositional Thermodynamics (Spencer Breiner, National Institute of Standards and Technologies, USA), Fuzzy Type Theory for Opinion Dynamics (Paige North, University of Pennsylvania, USA), A Compositional Theory of Timed and Probabilistic Processes (Nicoletta Sabadini, University of Insubria, Italy), and Algebraic Structures in Logic and Relations (Filippo Bonchi, University of Pisa, Italy). The program combines a five-month virtual collaboration component with an intensive in-person week, and gives students practice across all skills of the research process, including reading and discussing papers, informal presentations and collaboration, expository blog writing, conference talks, writing papers, and, where relevant, programming. Further details can be found at http://adjointschool.com.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Applied Category Theory (ACT) is a relatively new field of applied mathematics that seeks to use the tools from category theory – a branch of algebra that studies relationships, processes, translation, and systems – and uses it to solve concrete problems of interest to practitioners in science, engineering, and the humanities.

The Adjoint School is an annual training program for early-career researchers in applied category theory. Its objectives are to (1) increase ACT community infrastructure by strengthening professional networks, and attracting and training talented students; (2) build a more socially, culturally, and economically diverse field; (3) strengthen ties with industry partners; (4) pursue new lines of research and further existing lines of research.

To achieve these goals, the School comprises a five-month reading course on recent research in ACT, followed by a week-long research school mentored by senior ACT researchers, collocated with the annual International Conference on ACT. The students present their research during a special session at this conference, to an audience of academic and industry leaders. Participating in this school are the four organizers, plus four teams each comprising a Mentor who is an established research, a Teaching Assistant (TA) who is an early career mathematician in the Mentor’s area of research, and four Students who are typically graduate students or postdocs without direct experience in the Mentor’s area of research.

The 2022 Adjoint School research projects were

  • Compositional Thermodynamics

  • Fuzzy Type Theory for Opinion Dynamics

  • A Compositional Theory of Timed and Probabilistic Processes

  • Algebraic Structures in Logic and Relations

The Research Week was held at the University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, UK and findings were presented at the International Conference in Applied Category Theory at the same location the following week.

The 2023 Adjoint School research projects were

  • Message Passing Logic for Categorical Quantum Mechanics

  • Behavioural Metrics, Quantitative Logics and Coalgebras 

  • Concurrency in monoidal categories

  • Game Comonads and Finite Model Theory 

The Research Week was held at the University of Maryland, College Park and findings were presented at the International Conference in Applied Category Theory at the same location the following week.

Broader impacts include the training of talented students, facilitating a more inclusive and diverse STEM community, and providing network opportunities, including with industry. 

The training roles at the Adjoint School are the Students, the TA’s, and the Organizers. Student training is in conducting literature reviews, collaborative research, writing formal and informal mathematics, and presenting to experts. According to a survey conducted after the completion of the school, an overwhelming majority self-reported that they improved in each of these areas as a result of participating in the Adjoint School.  TA’s received training in the areas of managing research teams, such as facilitating inexperienced researchers to conduct literature reviews, to write formal and informal articles, and to create and deliver professional presentations. The Organizers, who are early career mathematicians, received training in the areas of organizing an event with many moving parts, planning activities involving researchers in varying career stages, managing participants to fill their various School roles, obtain required resources, and facilitate meetings. TAs and organizers also returned feedback that participating in the Adjoint School provides valuable development experience that is not typically available at such an early career stage. 

Another goal of the Adjoint School is to diversify the population who conduct research level mathematics.  Historically, over 35% of the Adjoint School participants are female, of minority gender, or BIPOC, all underrepresented communities in ACT. In 2023, that level was increased to over 50%.

The Adjoint School provided a quality networking opportunity in that it brought 29 researchers from international locations at various career stages together for 6 months (virtually) followed by a single week of working closely together.  Further networking opportunities were made possible by the student presentations to working category theorists at the International Applied Category Theory Conference during the week following the Adjoint School. Moreover, at the same conference, students had access to an Industry Information session including representatives from NIST, Conexus, Chevron, Statebox, Protocol Labs, Viete, Huawei, Cambridge Quantum, the Topos Institute, and Klick.

The Adjoint School has run annually since 2018. For more about the Adjoint School, see http://adjointschool.com/.
